author: PeteTheCameraman
body:
[Excerpt from Dr. Alexander Elder's: "The New Trading for a Living"](/r/wallstreetbets/comments/lxczpb/for_all_the_new_people_wondering_why_stock_charts/)
> *-Dr. Alexander Elder, Day Trader and Psychiatrist, "Trading for a Living"*
_______________________________________________________________________________
>Markets are loosely organized crowds whose members bet that prices will rise or fall. Since each price represents crowd consensus at the moment of transaction, trad- ers are betting on the future opinion and mood of the crowd. The crowd keeps swinging from hope to fear and from indifference to optimism or pessimism. Most people don’t follow their own trading plans because they get swept up in the crowd’s feelings and actions.
>People change when they join crowds.They become more credulous and impul- sive, anxiously search for a leader, and react to emotions instead of using their intel- lect. An individual who becomes involved in a group becomes less capable of think- ing for himself.
>Group members may catch a few trends, but they get killed when trends reverse. Successful traders are independent thinkers.

>Many traders are puzzled why markets reverse immediately after they dump their losing position.This happens because crowd members are gripped by the same fear— and everybody dumps at the same time. Once the selling fit has ended, the market has nowhere to go but up. Optimism returns to the marketplace, and the crowd forgets fear, grows greedy, and goes on a new buying binge.

>Crowds are primitive, and your trading strategies should be simple.You don’t have to be a rocket scientist to design a winning trading method. If the trade goes against you—cut your losses and run. Never argue with the crowd—simply use your judgment to decide when to join and when to leave.

>**Compare this to what happens to a man after a fall. If he falls down a few steps, he may dust himself off and run up again. But if he falls out of a second-story window, he’s not going to run anytime soon; he needs time to recover. Prices seldom rally immediately hard after a bad decline.**

_______________________________________________________________________________

author: EffingDankrupt
body:
I've been trying to post this since yesterday and it keeps getting deleted so I guess it's just a long ass comment now.  Mods please tell me why automod hates me?

 First of all, 🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀.

Second of all, I like the stock. Yes the stock. Not hating on those side hussies they just don't get me.

Thirdly of all, I have some interesting intel, some serious questions, and I would like to hear some serious explanations if this ever makes it out of the great filter.

1. The simple question first. I keep reading a lot of talk about available shares to cover short positions and all kinds of fancy maths to show all kinds of fancy scenarios. The problem I can't seem to get around is that there are millions of shares trading hands every fucking day, so what in the fuck are you talking about? If I were short 100,000 shares and I would like to close that position can't I just click the buy to close button and fuck off? Why the hell do I give a shit if these shares are real or synthetic or counterfeit or made out of construction paper? I just click the button and my position is closed. Why would this be any different for a hedge fund with a short position? Seriously though, I don't know the answer and I have not seen an answer so please somebody fill the gap here.
2. Holy fucking put options. I happened to take a peek at the option statistics today and there is some serious insanity that I can't come up with a reasonable explanation for. Hopefully one of you smooth brains has some logic that can be applied.

(There was a pic here of 646,379 puts)

guh

Holy fuckin puts batman

So.... thats a lot of puts. 646,379 to be exact (EDIT: plus another 300,000 today). The last time I saw that was the day before the stock took a huge dump a couple weeks ago. It was well planned and well executed. So I got more curious and decided to check out what exactly they are buying and/or selling so I can pucker the butthole.

(There was a pic here of hundreds of thousands of 1,2,3 strike worthless puts being bought)

holy smokes batman

Are you yanking my dick right now? Yes those are $1 strike puts.

WTF chuck. This page goes on like this forever. Yes, those are literally **hundreds of thousands** of puts, 500 per order, expiring in 6 fucking weeks, ranging from $1 strike price to $5 strike price. Is this a joke? Altogether my rough math is showing approximately 400,000 puts under $5 strike.

My first instinct was OH somebody is SELLING these puts to collect a massive premium payday when they expire worthless and this is BULLISH AF. But a few steps later I back tracked on that relief when the thought occurred to me that there is still somebody on the other side of every one of those trades who is buying them up 500 at a time every few minutes like candy. ?????. Confused emoji. Seriously, what the fuck is going on here.

1. Is $THETA gang just collecting their tendy premiums and taking advantage of high IV?
2. Is the stock about to file bankruptcy, liquidate, and move out of country all in less than 6 weeks?
3. Is this a reverse gamma squeeze play to drive the price down and force shorting?
4. Maybe I am a cat?
5. Is there a different game of chess happening here I am completely missing?

Like I said, I don't have any logical answers here but I am hoping you guys are able to detectify this a bit and make this make sense to me because I don't know what's going on here, but I do know that some kind of pretty serious fuckery is about to take place if it hasn't already.

Thank you for coming to my TED talk. As a reward, here are some more 🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀

author: italiangreenbeans
body:
It really depends on what happens in the future in terms of new chip sets and cards. The newest Ryzen chips are incredible, in terms of price to performance, and their newest set of graphics cards, while suffering from the same shortage as their only real competition, nVidia, have on par performance specs for 25% less. I've been an Intel/nVidia user since I built my first PC years ago, but in the last few generations of chips and cards, I've always recommended AMD products to my friends looking to build PCs. In fact, if you look on the logicalincrements website, which is a very popular resource for speccing out a new PC, each and every recommended CPU is AMD. They were small, and overlooked in the past, but they are dominating as of late.

Looking at the prices of the stocks, AMD is still less than 1/3 the market cap of NVDA, despite the fact that NVDA only makes GPUs, while AMD makes both CPUs and GPUs. If you look at Intel, they have 2.5x the market cap of AMD, and they only make CPUs.

With the way AMD's chips have been performing, and the fact that they are outperforming on both isles of the PC gaming industry, I think they'll end up doing very well. A stock price of $250+ is not out of the question imo.

author: gb2075
body:
I’ve been researching semi-conductors in depth the past few days. 

I’m eyeing the big retail guys like INTC, NVDA, AMD (agreed with you that AMD is the most promising).

The other segment is the fabricators, they don’t sell chips they just produce them for other companies. I’m keeping tabs on AMAT, TSM, LRCX, NXPI, FORM, UMC).

Then finally the rare earth metals.. companies like MP, AMAT, VALE (I was long on these guys then they got a fucking $7B fine for killing 300 people in a dam explosion.... oops).

Look into Biden’s recent executive order, not only does he address the global semiconductor shortage, but plans to bring jobs back to the states and invest in American companies. MP Materials is the only US based company REM company. 

This all looks so obvious as a long term play. I forget where I read it, but the global semiconductor usage is going to 10x or something insane like that in the next 10 years.

I don’t know why all of these companies are down recently, I haven’t looked into it. I bought $10 worth of every stock listed above so I could keep tabs on them. All of them have followed the same negative trajectory the last month or so. If you zoom out to 5 year though, almost every single company shows insane growth. I imagine that growth will only compound long term. Do you have any thoughts on the reason for this recent downward trend? 

I’m considering making a pretty massive 5-10 year long play on semiconductors.

INTC was the first stock I ever bought over a decade ago. It was a fantastic company, the name in the game for desktop computing.

A lot has changed.

Now, I'm gonna be blunt with these next statements... Being more than a year behind your direct competition in producing sub 10nm chips is not some minor issue, it is a big fucking deal.

This isn't something they'll solve next month. It's been something they've been planning, working on, for years without success. During this time your competition has solved it and is on track to lap them. Some of the largest fab capacity on the planet, and they can't produce a competitive product. If you're not the leader in a superior quality product to maintain market share, in semiconductors, it's not good.

author: Vander_chill

$TSM $AMD  There is a massive chip shortage!

Automakers have been slowing manufacturing and Toyota shut down its plant in Texas last month.  AAPL has issues keeping supply and it is no longer because of "trade issues with China".  There are not enough semiconductor chips to go around.

[TSM 1 year](https://imgur.com/679n2Pp)

The stock is 10% below its highs, but there is no reason to believe this upward trend won't continue.  They are swimming in cash and business is at full capacity and growing.

...on the actual chip side, $AMD has gotten hammered recently but its prospects for growth are still looking robust.  Their Radeon chip series are the preferred choice for the crypto industry which is only growing.

author: topdangle
body:
AMD used to be undervalued. They may be slightly undervalued now due to people cashing out during this mining craze in preparation for the inevitable flood of used cards coming back into the market and killing revenue, but they're still floating around the right price looking at TSMC's capacity and AMD's forward projections. AMD themselves are looking at 2025 before they grow past their current value. If you're just talking memes I guess they have room to grow but I think sentiment has been turning against them due to absurd GPU prices.

Saying amd is the most innovative graphics card company is just plain crazy. They caught up to nvidia in raster performance thanks to completely dropping their compute architecture in favor of raster performance, yet they're only about nvidia level of performance even after losing significant efficiency in compute. Meanwhile you've got nvidia slapping on RT/Tensor with every gpu, codeveloping PAM4 memory and somehow managing to still provide similar raster. Catching up to your competitor by stripping utility is not innovative.

If anything AMD is being carried by its innovative CPU designs pushing chiplets years before intel while intel is praying 3dstacking closes the gap. Their GPU division however just constantly struggles and has yet to ship a competitive instinct GPU. They've basically given up on competing with nvidia in enterprise and instead are taking intel's scientific compute market with high FP64 gpus. It's led to some big supercomputer wins but overall their GPU division hasn't pushed the envelope since the 290x. Honestly I'm surprised that cray believes they will ship Frontier on schedule since AMD's instinct GPUs barely even exist, but they said they're on schedule so maybe AMD's gpu division has bigger improvements on the horizon for 5nm.

author: ThatLawTalkinGuy
body: Ultimately, the CEO change was the catalyst for me. The risk-reward proposition is good. If a turnaround is effectuated, it has the potential to 3x in order to trade in line with its peers. At 12 times earnings and a 2%+ dividend, the stock is cheap, so the downside risk is minimal. INTC's legacy PC-centric business is growing, but it doesn't trade like it (the market just assumes that PCs are a dead growth category). And you get the faster-growing data center, self-driving MobilEye, and all the Intel VC businesses. MobilEye is particularly exciting. As a standalone business, I believe it would trade at something like a $25 billion market cap in this market - maybe higher.

author: pastrybaker
body:
Is anyone else pretty impressed that it's holding at these levels even though it's off the SSR today? 

According to [https://iborrowdesk.com/report/GME](https://iborrowdesk.com/report/GME), there was some big shorting going on this morning through Interactive Brokers. So, we could assume the same was happening with other brokers. At the same time, I know that at least TDA isn't allowing short selling of GME at all (was on the phone with them the other day, and the guy told me they haven't allowed it since the end of January).

Still, the price has not only held, but risen pretty significantly today. I'm having a hard time seeing the downside to continuing to hold, I just don't think it's a wise thing to sell at this point. The gamma squeeze seems like it'll happen, the short squeeze is likely too. And even if it's not, the company is pivoting and may become a big player in the years to come. All those things are why I will keep holding.

At the same time, if you haven't covered your initial investment, please do so. I sold off enough at the end of January to pay off almost $50k of CC debt and to have a bit leftover to provide for me and my kids. Now I'm playing with house money, so it's easier for me to weather the dips.

I'm holding 307 shares @ \~$70 per share. I also have a 17 calls for different dates.

author: willy-fistergash08
body:
Things we should keep in mind today:


•	⁠There is no way to predict when the squeeze will happen
	⁠•	⁠There will be crazy price action in both directions
	⁠•	⁠This can go on as long as the shorts remain solvent
	⁠•	⁠The longer they drag this out, the higher it goes
	⁠•	⁠People might say, "Lift-Off in 10!" But they're just excited
	⁠•	⁠Nobody knows when it'll happen or how high it will go

Basically, don't believe the hype, but feel free to join in. You should do your own research, read the DD, and make informed decisions. Don't invest money you can't afford to lose.

In other words, fuck safely, or you'll get fucked.

•	⁠There is no "we."
	⁠•	⁠I'm holding because that's my choice. I believe in GME
	⁠•	⁠I will not buy because someone else says to do so
	⁠•	⁠I will not encourage others to buy
	⁠•	⁠Nothing I say is financial advice
	⁠•	⁠If you're confused, read the rules. No market manipulation.

Report posts that encourage everyone to buy at the same time. The primary reason for this is legal, but the secondary is that the media will cherry-pick comments like this to give us a bad name and put more negativity out there through their articles, broadcasts, etc.

•	⁠There will be plenty of FUD (or "fear, uncertainty, and doubt")
	⁠•	⁠I am including this out of belief, if not pure spite
	⁠•	⁠There are redditors being paid to scare you
	⁠•	⁠There are bots made to SPAM negativity
	⁠•	⁠There are people profiting when you sell
	⁠•	⁠This starts ramping up in the afternoon

There are two sides to this fight, and we have to remember that there are people profiting if we fail. There are people playing the other side who will come into the thread and try to throw us off track by ruining the morale. We mustn't give in to them. Besides, they can't even provide any good DD for their bear-case, it's all just "sElL iT's OvEr."

•	⁠This is the motherfucking GME Megathread
	⁠•	⁠Do not push other tickers
	⁠•	⁠Do not jingle keys in our faces
	⁠•	⁠Fuck you

I, personally, go out of my way to CTRL/CMD+F and search for other tickers. If you're bringing up non-GME stocks in order to distract the thread, I'm one of the downvotes on your comment. Sue me.

	⁠•	⁠We can name our price

But they don't understand just how dumb we really are. We are far too stupid to be afraid of their fearmongering, and we'll hold 'til the moon.

If you haven’t already. Read this... A few lines about GME (please read)

1. Price doesn't matter until the squeeze has been squoze.
2. The best time to buy GME was 2 months ago, the second best time is NOW.
3. Buy shares, not options. Invest only the money you can afford to lose.
4. Don't fall for FUD. Any account can be a shill/bot, even the ones created before January. They are PAYING users to spread fear and enroll you to post negative comments/posts.
5. GME has been and will always be the only play. Anything else is a distraction to limit the impact GME can have. (Yes, even RKT). Never will the planets align this perfectly again to trigger the biggest short squeeze of your lifetime.
6. The most important point : Don't sell. Supply and demand : you have something they want, we all do. So YOU set the price you want. And the price can actually go up to infinity. This is going to be the biggest transfer of wealth the world has ever seen, don't ruin it being a paper hand and selling low.
7. Hold. Hold. Hold. Selling at 1k is trolling. They want you to sell at 1k, that's why they keep spamming comments saying they put stop limits at 1k. 1k is lowball. 1k could just be a gamma squeeze. 10k is lowball.
8. As stated by u/Polihanna, the squeeze will last multiple days. Don't be afraid that it lasts a few seconds and you'll miss it. You won't. 
9. Don't day-trade GME. It's extremely volatile, and you actually help them by selling shares that they can buy for cheap. You delay the squeeze and reduce its impact if you day-trade.
10. THIS IS NOT A GAME OF GREED. IT IS A GAME OF TRUST.

author: stoney-the-tiger
body:
After I got married and started a family 2008, I threw all my Roth IRA into MSFT, Panasonic, TSM, and QQQ and didn't really look at it for about 8 years...  The main reason was because I was too busy with work and family to spend time investing. It grew a lot because I was in some very good names.  I got more involved because I had rolled over a 401k to an IRA and needed to re-deploy.  There were too many good companies available really cheap so after I had invested the IRA I moved on to my Roth.  But since then I have invested into a more diversified but still very tech heavy portfolio.  I sold the Panasonic & TSM first, then the QQQ, finally sold my last MSFT a couple months ago.  

Lately, I have been going with a much more active strategy holding usually 6-18 months.  I still have the first position I got into from Panasonic proceeds, $TEAM (I got in at $52.87/share).  

My advice would be don't get emotional about selling a position you have held for a really long time if you find a better opportunity.  I also think that the walking away for a long time was a good move for me because being this active takes a lot of time doing research and tracking the news.  It would have detracted from my career path and family to do it between 2018-2016 and my portfolio size wasn't large enough to make the extra returns worthwhile.

author: outphase84
body:
Welp, your DD falls on its face here.

Salesforce's acquisitions aren't a result of trying to pump revenue on the bottomline, it's a combination of moving into adjacent marketspace without R&D investment, and staying competitive with competing offers.

Your Slack example is a perfect example.  Their valuation was $25B, and you need to pay a premium in order to acquire a company.  And the play wasn't a result of trying to get Slack's revenue or profit.  Microsoft has been pushing Dynamics *hard* as part of the O365 licensing model.  That's a direct competitor to SFDC.  And MSFT's message that their sales org is pushing is "We hit all of your software needs with one license."  The biggest driver of upsales on O365 are Dynamics and Teams.  Bundling CRM and UCaaS is a gamechanger, and has been wildly successful for them.

SFDC needed to be able to compete with that bundling.  So they bought the biggest competitor to Teams.  And they'll bundle it with SFDC licenses.

Tableau is a similar purchase.  BI is a huge play right now, and *also* a feature that MSFT is bundling with O365.  Adding Tableau into the fold allows SFDC to directly compete with MSFT on that front, too.

These aren't cookie jar acquisitions, they're competitive expansion via acquisition.

author: calipfarris01
body: As of now, this is a "special dividend" which is a one time occurrence.  Not many companies do this, as a comparison Microsoft did this as well in 2004.  Had you been accumulating Microsoft over the years since 2004, you'd be doing pretty well today.  I think the special dividend is meant to show that they value the shareholders and payback that growth.  They want to be considered a fintech company though (a growth company) and not a value stock, so I would imagine they will resist issuing more dividends in the near term.  That doesn't mean 10 years from now they wont.  This is the kind of stock you hold on to (IMO) and don't worry about "thinking it will dump".  As I've described the price will take at least a 5% loss (probably more) after March 9th when people sell after the div payment.  What they don't realize is by doing that they are actually losing money. Yes they got the dividend but they also took the share price decrease and the additional decrease from the other sellers, which in the example above, would be more than the $1,100 you get issued (i.e. a net negative investment). You can short term play it if you like but your profits are only going to be in what the stock price rises between now and the div payment.  If you plan to sell directly after March 9, just know you are probably losing money.  You would need to hold after the 9th until the stock price rises a bit (hopefully).  OR you can just continue to hold a great stock, which to me is the better move.

body:
With all due respect, I do not agree with your statement about there being direct competitors for most companies between the NASDAQ and NYSE. Strong, long lasting companies like Apple, Microsoft, Nvidia, Qualcomm, etc. hardly have any competition whatsoever in reference to the companies listed in the NYSE (unless you count stagnant/dying firms like Oracle or Nokia, but that’s really stretching it). Only thing I can really think of is Facebook v Twitter and some e-commerce stuff like Alibaba v Amazon. Either way, the examples are seldom. 

That said, I appreciate your advice immensely. Thank you :)

author: Psychological_Dot541
body:
$GSAT = buyout target 

   QUALCOMM- and -ERICSSON 

APR 2, 2019:
Former Qualcomm boss pivots toward 5G startup XCOM.

SEP 17, 2020: 
Ericsson, Qualcomm, and U.S. Cellular announce first ever successful extended range 5G NR millimeter Wave (mmWave) data call in the U.S. on a commercial network.

OCT 9, 2020:
Ericsson selected for U.S .DOD 5G testing.

NOV 11, 2020:
Ericsson stock growth is tied to 5G expansion.

FEB 9, 2021: 
Qualcomm includes Globalstar's Band n53 in its new 5G X65 modem. The X65 is Qualcomm's flagship 5G modem and adds global 5G band support for n53.

FEB 17, 2021:
GLOBALSTAR ANNOUNCES STRATEGIC ALLIANCE WITH XCOM LABS.

author: maddogenglish
body: Finally a warm day in Colorado so I'm going golfing tomorrow. I would appreciate it if PLTR, SNDL, QCOM, FCEL, QQQ and CAM bring in some ![img](emote|wsb_emojis|tendies) while I am away. Please make that happen.

author: Psychological_Dot541
body: 5G is a fiercely competitive market. The United States will beat Huawei to establish the global standards and commercial market for security reasons - ergo the most prominent U.S. company is in Globalstar given that it already has trusted partners in both Qualcomm (and Ericsson by association) - both of which bring integrated services to 190+ countries.

author: notpr1m
body:
Yes. Buy AMD. Better tech than Intel but cheaper than NVIDIA, no fabrication operations because they were losing money on it a few years ago so sold it off to focus on design, which I think gives them more flexibility to adapt to capitalize on any investments that could be coming from the public sector, and they probably aren’t bleeding money from production constraints like the others. Probably the best CEO in the space as well. 

I also like Qualcomm a lot for similar reasons, but also because they’re positioned to win big in 5G and will probably do well in the IoT space as well. Much more mature company too with a nice dividend ($.65/share).

SEP 17, 2020: 
Ericsson, Qualcomm, and U.S. Cellular announce first ever successful extended range 5G NR millimeter Wave (mmWave) data call in the U.S. on a commercial network.

OCT 9, 2020:
Ericsson selected for U.S .DOD 5G testing.

NOV 11, 2020:
Ericsson stock growth is tied to 5G expansion.

FEB 9, 2021: 
Qualcomm includes Globalstar's Band n53 in its new 5G X65 modem. The X65 is Qualcomm's flagship 5G modem and adds global 5G band support for n53.

FEB 17, 2021:
GLOBALSTAR ANNOUNCES STRATEGIC ALLIANCE WITH XCOM LABS.

author: labattblueenthusiast
body:
I recently saw an [article](https://www.google.com/amp/s/www.marketwatch.com/amp/story/25-shares-of-companies-backed-by-rapid-earnings-growth-as-the-economy-reopens-11614704694) on MarketWatch that lists undervalued stocks based on potential earnings as the economy reopens. They have a great chart that breaks down company, industry, estimated earnings per share in a 12 month period, the trailing EPS, sales growth (if applicable), speculative price target and a dividend yield. This is a very thorough list and has companies such as many major banks, Cummins (CMI), Qualcomm (QCOM), World Fuel Services (INT) to name a few (there are many more). My personal choice would be KemPharm Inc (KMPH). Outlined [here](https://money.cnn.com/quote/forecast/forecast.html?symb=KMPH) is a CNN Business breakdown giving the now $16 share a $28 price target (price is on the rise since last night when they received their FDA approval.

EDIT: Do your own DD, I am not a financial advisor, can not confirm nor deny stocks only go up.

author: Flam3Shot_
body:
With all due respect, I do not agree with your statement about there being direct competitors for most companies between the NASDAQ and NYSE. Strong, long lasting companies like Apple, Microsoft, Nvidia, Qualcomm, etc. hardly have any competition whatsoever in reference to the companies listed in the NYSE (unless you count stagnant/dying firms like Oracle or Nokia, but that’s really stretching it). Only thing I can really think of is Facebook v Twitter and some e-commerce stuff like Alibaba v Amazon. Either way, the examples are seldom. 

That said, I appreciate your advice immensely. Thank you :)
